page.title: 04Banstead Wood Trees/Shrubs
page.content: The north downs chalk, although close to the surface, is overlain here by 'clay-with-flints' a common drift deposit. Apart from a small flat top, the wood slopes to NNE. On the nutrient-rich lower slopes (115 m) the woody flora is very mixed and includes; Hazel, Elder, Ash, Birch, Dogwood, Field Maple, Goat Willow Sycamore, Oak, Yew, Holly, Hawthorn, Gean, Rowan, Bramble, Ivy, Dogrose, Raspberry, Honeysuckle, and Old Man's Beard. Higher up at 140 m, Beech appears and becomes abundant since the chalk is only 60cm down in places. On the flat area at 160 m an even mixture of Oak and Beech appears. In this wood Ash, Oak and Beech are all showing a reasonable age diversity. In some places where senile trees have been lost the Council have tried some replanting. Ground flora on page 05.
